Imagine the smell, that rotting putrid meat smell, the dried blood rotten fruit stench permeating all around the wet ripe jungle mud and coating your nose and skin and eyes and tongue with its 100-degree tropical humidity.

That's what my shit smells like after a night of Indian food. Don't get me wrong, I love my lamb vindaloo, but some mornings I wonder if it was worth it.

>>18861512
if its buds, 5g/100ml 80-85c, 15seconds then either +5 or +15 seconds with each additional steep. buds can get very bitter but i think they do better with longer gongfu steepings.
if its leaves the same but you can use full boiling, but tend to do better with shorter steeps. some people also simmer the leaves in a saucepan for a long time.

i find whites to be the hardest to brew right because they all seem to require different parameters where as black/oolongs/green ect call brew up well with the same parameters i.e all blacks behave the same, all whites behave differently at least for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18861512
>>18862215
You need to full soak the buds to get them to start extracting, which takes a pretty long time. Depending on your preference, you can do a fairly long hard rinse, boiling water for 30s or more depending on how dense your buds are, or you can do a short rinse, 5-10s at with boiling water, then a long brew, say 30s with boiling water. Once the leaves seem soaked through, they'll noticeably extract much faster. Do 10-15s brews here, if your tea is pleasant but thin, use more leaf, I brew with a very high ratio of leaf to water for baihao yinzhen. If it starts to be astringent or develop off flavors, you can do your main brews at around 90C instead. Once the leaves start to thin out, I like to do a single minute long brew, then a five minute brew and end it.

It will depend on the leaves you have, but the basic profile should look like that. Long brew to soak the leaves and get them to open up a bit, successions of much shorter brews, a few long brews. At close to boiling or boiling water, but feel free to lower the temperature if you feel you need to.

>>18871841
My biggest advice is that real, professional tasting is hard, and you shouldn't worry about giving brief or simple tasting notes. Trying to force it doesn't really work. When you're starting out you'll mostly give notes like woody, nutty, earthy etc. as you taste more stuff and have a better calibration, you'll start to find different sorts of flavors that can be consistent across different teas that you'll want to look for words to describe. I think it's fun, but a lot of the cultural and focus around tasting is people like Mei Leaf, who do it as a performance and not as any serious exercise. China has a robust culture around tea tasting and evaluation, but it mostly hasn't been exported from what I've seen.

posts.com: what's the general difference in taste between small and large leaf ripe pu-erhs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873668
This is very general
Smaller leafs and buds, stronger, more bitter, infuses faster, runs out out flavor in less brews. Larger leaves + stems, sweeter, more mellow, smoother, less strong brews but more of them.
But its going to vary based on processing, fermentation level, the batch of tea leaves used etc.

Like I said, I've experienced first-hand in various green tea drinking countries in Asia like Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and China, that they don't brew at a specific temperature, they just pour boiling water straight into the pot. If you go to these countries and suggest using 90 degree water you will just get laughed out of the room like the autist you are.

From my own personal experience, boiling water doesn't make green tea bitter. What makes it bitter is:
- shitty quality tea leaves, usually from a bag
- not allowing the leaves room to expand, such as using an infuser basket
- adding too many leaves to the pot

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tea beginner here.
I tried and liked Bigelow's oolong, but Twinings is lighter, less earthy, and more of a green tea flavor to it. Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?
I prefer Bigelow's to Twining's here. What beginner-level brands should I look for?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
oolong is one of the most varied categories of tea, because it can be more or less oxidized. the less oxidized stuff is closer to green tea, more oxidized to black tea generally. also, oolong can be roasted to various degrees, which can also change the flavor completely. there are many different types of oolong, some of them can be very fresh and smell of flowers and fruit, while others are bready, nutty, sweet or even minetal in taste

you generally shouldn't buy tea by prepackaged supermarket brands if you want to buy good quality stuff. you should be buying it from trusted vendors, who you can find in the pastebin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
>Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?
yes you can get big variation in tea picked from the same mountain. oolongs typically come either as fermented 'green tea' or oxidised fermented 'black tea'
>What beginner-level brands should I look for?
loose will always be better than bagged, get a gaiwan or brewing basket that fits in your mug. vahdam is good for indian and sells on amazon, im guessing as your just starting out you wouldn't want to dive right in to importing from chinese suppliers. look out for iron goddess of mercy/Tieguanyin and Da Hong Pao/Big Red Robe. you'll be able to get both off amazon/tea houses/chinese stores although buying off an actual tea seller will give better quality and probably a little cheaper/quality

>How exactly does one pry apart a tuo?
Put the tuo down with the dent on the bottom, go around about an inch from the edge with the pick and push downwards/pry outwards. Once you have the loosest tea around the edges removed you can either pry a layer off the top or just break the rest into chunks with your fingers.

>how the fuck are they thin?
i lived in japan for 12 years
here's the quick rundown

>walk literally everywhere
>culture pushes almost everyone into being part of a sports club or fitness activity
>small portions (a "meal" in japan is 400~600kcal)
>smaller everything (a typical 'large' packet of chips in Japan is only 50g)
>they actually hydrate, japs drink unsweetened iced tea (oolong, mugi etc) or green tea constantly
>compulsory Home Ec classes from 4th grade until end of highschool. they learn how to actually cook, like making say miso soup or curry from scratch, how to gut and clean a fish etc
>4h of PE classes a week
>half of their PE classes are theory, where they learn how to count calories, balance healthy meals, how to calculate how much of each vitamin/mineral is in a meal etc
>school sports clubs, jap schools basically bully kids into joining some sort of after school club, which is a 12~20h a week commitment. this continues from age 10 until age 22 or so, until
>office jobs often have a compulsory "volleyball hangout" or some sort of sports thing they do with their coworkers a couple times a month
i could go on but you get the idea

most of it boils down to
>they exercise constantly
>they hydrate well
>all of their food & portions are much smaller

>>18861195
Didn’t drink until I was 17, at the after party to my high school ball (I guess burgers would call it prom). Then I got the taste for it.
Was fine for 2 years, alcoholic for 3, fine for another 3, alcoholic for another 3, and now I’m starting to clean up my act for my job. I know people here won’t sympathise or believe me, but my life has improved immensely in the last year through slow tapering.
I’m down to moderately drinking once a week, which is much better than being heavily dependant every day. It just took very small things like dropping a % per vol here and there, and buying slightly less every time you go to the shop.
I recently got back my taste for alcohol for the first time in god knows how long. I actually crave a good beer for the taste, or a good bourbon on the rocks.

tl;dr alcoholism sucks but you can still beat it by being smart. But I ain’t gonna blame you if you don’t want to, it’s your choice.

The silt is part of the experience for a french press, but if it really bothers you consider getting a 200 micron filter device. It feels kinda wasteful discarding some of your grounds, but will negate your issue. You can also use the filter to help prevent paper/cloth filter clogging.

>>18873838
Watch for fines in your grinds. Give the brewing grinds a stir and time to settle to the bottom. Pour slowly and maybe discard the last couple ounces. You might even also spoon off the first crema as I find that really improves the clarity of the cup. The FP shouldn't rely on the screen. It helps but gravity does most of your filtering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18875263
There's really no point in spending more on a French Press. Most of the "premium" features you'd get on more expensive models (borosilicate or stainless vs cheap soda-lime glass; dual wall/insulation vs single wall; etc) are kind of pointless in a French Press. Because it's an immersion brewer, you shouldn't be leaving the grounds and water in there long enough for heat loss to be an issue, and even the cheapest, thinnest soda-lime glass won't experience catastrophic thermal shock at 100°C. Now, having said all that, if my cheap chinkshit French Press broke, I'd probably replace it with an Espro P3. I'd be interested in seeing how/if the dual mesh basket affects the brew.

Cool, dark, temp stable place. Opaque container would be ideal, but its more about minimizing air exchange for longer term storage. I use mason jars with (salvaged)one way valves for the coffees I'm currently resting, then divide them out into convenient portions to vac seal and freeze. Sort of depends on what you want to drink, and how much work you're willing to put in to drink it. An Aeropress will get you brewed coffee; users will claim you can get espresso out of it, but they're going to hell for lying. It's far easier to use than a Mini/Nano, though. The Mini/Nano has the added benefit of taking pods, if you don't want to carry around a grinder or pre-ground coffee, but since it's closer to an actual espresso machine, it'll be more finnicky about temperature, while also being more work to produce coffee. I don't use either an Aeropress or a Mini/Nanopresso, but I do use a Picopresso as a daily driver espresso machine, but I can't imagine using that at school, but that machine is far more finnicky about all of the various coffee variables, since it's an actual espresso machine. For the record, I think Wacaco, the company behind all of the various [word for small]-presso products is also Chinese. And if you think a device similar to a Minipresso is a pain in the ass to use, I can't imagine a Mini or Nano being any less of a pain in the ass.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18883844
Depends on other variables too. Things that increase extraction:
>more finely ground coffee
>darker roasts
>higher temperatures
>longer brew times
>larger amount of water (during brewing)
And the opposites decrease it obviously. You don't want your coffee to be over or under extracted so you need to find the right balance. Generally it's recommended to only fiddle with one variable at a time and keeping the rest consistent.

This is King Arthur Flour's recipe, works like a charm. Differences though:

- glaze while still semi-warm so glaze looks purdy
- I like to use half butter and half lard for the batter, doughnuts turn out more fluffy.

idk a recipe, really.
I'll try.
Black eyed peas cooked plain from a half pound dry
Two large chopped onions
8ish cloves of garlic, minced
8 ish chopped green goats horns (the long, curvy, wrinkly chillis)
A pound of blanched tomatoes
A peeled and chopped hand of ginger
Water, as needed
Like a half cup or more ooking oil or ghee
Various spices according to your tastes or family tradition. Mine is turmeric powder, cumin, mustard, caraway, saunth, hing, paprika, cayenne powder, neem leaves and prolly some other stuff in forgetting
Cilantro leaves

Put the cooked peas in a pot
Add water to cover
Boil
Reduce until thick and starchy; meanwhile, use the aromatics to make the wet masala then add it to the beans
Mix
Cook some more, adding water, if necessary
Temper the spices in the oil/ghee then pour into the curry
Stir to mix then serve, adding cilantro at the end

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I dont even like beans, but I could eat this for every single meal. The smoked ham hock or shank is essential. Also, I dont use a slow cooker, I throw it in a 325*F oven for like five hours.


2 tablespoons vegetable oil
1 large yellow onion, finely chopped
Kosher salt and black pepper
3 celery stalks, finely chopped
1 green bell pepper, finely chopped
10 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 teaspoon garlic powder
1 teaspoon onion powder
1 teaspoon sweet paprika
½ to 1 teaspoon ground cayenne, plus more to taste
½ teaspoon ground sage (optional)
1 pound dried red kidney beans, soaked overnight
3 dried bay leaves
3 sprigs fresh thyme or 1 teaspoon dried thyme
12 ounces smoked pork sausage, preferably Andouille, sliced into 1-inch-thick coins
1 smoked ham hock or shanks (about 10 ounces)
Cooked rice, for serving
Sliced scallions, for serving
Louisiana-style hot sauce, for serving


Step 1
Heat the oil in a large (12-inch) skillet over medium. Add the onion, season with salt, and cook, stirring, until the onion is limp and translucent, 6 to 8 minutes. Add the celery and bell pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, 5 to 8 minutes. Add the chopped garlic, garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, cayenne and sage (if using); grind in a generous amount of black pepper and add ¾ teaspoon salt. Stir well to combine all the ingredients, then remove from the heat and scrape the mixture into a 6- to 8-quart slow cooker.

Step 2
Add the beans, bay leaves, thyme, sausage, ham hock and 6 cups water. Cook on high until the beans are very tender and creamy, about 7 hours.

Step 3
Before serving, add salt or cayenne to taste. Using a fork or the back of a spoon, mash some of the beans against the side of the slow cooker to make the mixture slightly creamy. (It will continue to thicken as it sits.) Discard the bay leaves and thyme sprigs; you can pick the meat off the ham hock if you like. Top the beans with hot cooked rice and scallions; serve with hot sauce.

For plain beans:

Soak them 6+ hours. You can let them soak up to 24 in my experience.

Dump out the water. Put them in a pot with new water. Bring to a boil for a minute or two. Reduce to a simmer. Add more water if needed. Taste the beans every so often to see if they're soft enough yet. Once they're soft enough, take them off the stove and drain the bean water.

>>18879035
Very little meat. Very little cheese. Almost entirely plants. Most of their protein came from beans.
Mostly their diet consisted of extremely coarse, unpleasant barley bread (easier to grow than wheat, but it tastes bad).
Generally peasants wouldn't be malnourished– there'd be enough food for most of the year, but consistent periods of severe hunger during lean years. Medieval commoners were around 7 inches shorter on average than people are today.
All the animal products, nuts, and other proteins that allow people to grow to a healthy size were too resource intensive for the poor to afford; even those that could access them were often better off selling them for more grain.
This improved significantly after the black plague killed a third of the population. Europe was heavily overpopulated in the high middle ages relative to its technological carrying capacity.

>>18879035
Due to crop rotation being necessary they ate a lot of beans and similar things. Bread being another staple, there is a reason they mention daily bread in the lord's prayer it's not just a metaphor. A lot of root vegetables during the winter, with a variety of seasonal crops. Fish was very important as well and a reason beyond trade for coastal cities being the largest in general.
As for meat most of the animals you raised for other things such as milk, wool and eggs so you would only eat them when they were too old to provide these things giving poor quality and though meat. So quality beef and lamb etc was pretty much only for the rich. Pigs however were raised for meat even by the lower classes as you could have them find food in woods you otherwise wouldn't get any food out of anyway. Hunted meat would also be had in the rural areas. A large part of why the norman king's forest laws were so hated in England were so hated is because it prevented the common people from having access to these two types of meat which they had earlier.

I'm the guy with the $1k Japanese rice cooker if you've followed any of the rice cooking threads. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18872424
My research led me to discover this perfect recipe for short grain rice, but my rice cooker actually does a better job. My old zoji didn't, but this one does.

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

>>18872761

39. We use the term “surrogate activity” to designate an activity that is directed toward an artificial goal that people set up for themselves merely in order to have some goal to work toward, or let us say, merely for the sake of the “fulfillment” that they get from pursuing the goal. Here is a rule of thumb for the identification of surrogate activities. Given a person who devotes much time and energy to the pursuit of goal X, ask yourself this: If he had to devote most of his time and energy to satisfying his biological needs, and if that effort required him to use his physical and mental faculties in a varied and interesting way, would he feel seriously deprived because he did not attain goal X? If the answer is no, then the person’s pursuit of goal X is a surrogate activity. Hirohito’s studies in marine biology clearly constituted a surrogate activity, since it is pretty certain that if Hirohito had had to spend his time working at interesting non-scientific tasks in order to obtain the necessities of life, he would not have felt deprived because he didn’t know all about the anatomy and life-cycles of marine animals. On the other hand the pursuit of sex and love (for example) is not a surrogate activity, because most people, even if their existence were otherwise satisfactory, would feel deprived if they passed their lives without ever having a relationship with a member of the opposite sex. (But pursuit of an excessive amount of sex, more than one really needs, can be a surrogate activity.)

I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

>>18879090
I have this stuff, which, along with coconut oil is what everyone says to buy to make "movie theater popcorn". I very much disagree with this. Flavacol and coconut oil is what you should buy if you want your stovetop popcorn to taste exactly like microwave popcorn.

If you want good buttered popcorn, in my experience what you want is clarified butter. I would not buy it pre-made, either. The pre-made stuff tasted funky to me. It's easy to make, you just simmer the butter until the solids separate and then pour them off. Butter is really expensive right now, though.

Another tasty butter-based option is to use coconut oil or some other high-smoke-point oil, and then throw some fresh butter in right before it stops popping. This will make brown butter popcorn, which is good with some salt and sugar kettlecorn style. It has to go in right at the end though, or else it will burn.

You are essentially making what's called "aroma oil" in Japan/ramen world. You can get some good ideas if you search that.

The other cuisine that does something similar is Indian cooking. It's called tempering and you get oil super fucking hot then dump it all over a blend of herbs and spices. Once it cools some you pour that oil on top of whatever Indian sloppa you have made.

Both are really excellent additions to their respective foods.

>>18870294
I worked for an airline catering company. LSG. Bizarre how all that shit gets on and removed from flights. Most is frozen. Everything has strict specs for weight, count, etc. Fruit n cheese plates, salads, and first class for specific airlines is fresh made in house. Delta, United, Alaskan, and British Airways are pretty solid and fresh. Everything American Airlines is frozen. The bizarre amount of special meals available was irritating. Vegan, veg, Muslim, kosher, etc. Kosher meals came 100 percent frozen and shrink wrapped on serving trays. The rest are a pain. Nobody adhered to any of the Muslim meal/kitchen guidelines, but the end result fit the parameters.

What made it bad in the old days, besides general low quality of food, was also poor quality control to the end, such as improper microwaving etc. At some point they realized it isn't difficult to make all the airplane microwaves identical, have the food frozen relatively consistently, and make it all into a foolproof procedure.

Of course any domestic or non-transoceanic flight I've been on that's been long enough for a full meal has just served stuff that doesn't need heating, like sandwiches.

there is so much talk of airplane food being bland, myself, i loved the airplane food, perhaps it was the excitement, civilian airplanes are in my eyes among the most beautiful machines man has ever built, sitting comfortably at ~10km altitude, oftentimes with a magical view, hearing the sound of the wind rushing over the airframe, hearing the muffled sound of people talking, having a trey served with various little food items.. to me, it was the whole package, it was the experience i appreciated, it crushes my soul that those days are vanishing, as if they never existed, oh how i yearn for the 80s and 90s, how i yearn for sitting next to someone i love, eating a meal, drifting away into fantasy-land, dreaming of the alien world ahead of me, perhaps we dont deserve such magic anymore, perhaps we never did, perhaps it was i that never deserved it

I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called Linux, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called Linux distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux!

I believe ideally you should *warm* your non-coated stainless steel(~200°F), add oil, then continue heating to your desired cooking temp(300°-400°F).
Thermic shock and warping will still be an issue if you leave the empty pan unattended and add stuff to it after it's been superheated.
With a ceramic-coated or seasoned cast iron pan I don't think the pore stuff should be a thing and you can add the oil colder.

>>18872050
Cast iron has more mass therefore it has better thermal mass. Why is that important? Let's take one of the most used purposes for cast iron, pan seared steak. In pan searing a steak, surface temperature is critical to making a good sear. Once the steak is placed on the pan, the temperature will drop momentarily as the two surfaces work their way into equalizing their temperatures. A good sear requires maintaining as close temperature of the Maillard Reaction as possible, which is roughly around 357*F but requires a surface temperature greater than that since the steak is colder as both surfaces fight to equalize their temperatures. A cast iron skillet with more thermal mass than a stainless steel skillet will resist that temperature gradient longer than a stainless skillet because stainless steel is both less massive as well as less conductive.

With all that said however, I'm a stainless steel guy simply because itjustwerks™

>>18874654
If you are restoring an old, dirty pan from the flea market or fleabay, then this is good advice for an initial seasoning. If you're trying to build up a long-lasting seasoning this way, you will need to repeat this process many, many times. It can definitely work, but just understand that the natural seasoning in your grandma's pan got there after decades of daily use or use multiple times per day.

IMO, the best advice is to just cook in your pan and the seasoning will tend to build up naturally, but there are two complications. 1) Many ex-teflon users don't really know how to cook with oil and fuck up out of ignorance, and 2) if someone wants to cook meat in a new pan, right away, the seasoning will usually not be tough enough. Since most of the small scale/"boutique" cast iron manufacturers only ship their pan with an initial (thin) layer of seasoning, they tend to get a bad reputation when someone puts a steak into the pan, and then after cooking, they notice a steak-shaped spot where all the seasoning stripped off the cooking surface.

Just cook in the pan a lot. That's it. Even illiterate hillbillies can do it.

Enough scrubbing with dish soap and an abrasive scrubber can certainly affect the seasoning, but I'm sure you have a baking sheet somewhere that has some "stains" on it that are impossible to remove, even after soaking, scrubbing and then a pass in the dishwasher. That is seasoning. It's polymerized oil--it's changed into a different material and can no longer be considered oil.

Also, "patina" is again a different concept. Patina refers to a partially rusted layer of metal, usually black or dark brown rather than the usual tan/red or rust. Patina is more stable than rust, but has nothing to do with seasoning. You can patina a carbon steel knife by just using it normally.

posts.com:
>>18881113
Just do what he did. Most people have only cooked eggs on teflon their whole lives and don't realize you need to learn a slightly different technique on cast iron and stainless. Teflon is really forgiving. I used to cook eggs on high heat with a tiny, tiny amount of butter, but if I try the same settings on CI, it will stick no matter what.

On cast iron, you need at least a thin film of oil, like the guy in that incessantly reposted video uses. If your eggs are swimming in oil, that's fine too, just an option. Butter tends to be very forgiving for some reason, and the flavor goes well with eggs, but you can use any suitable oil. With CI, the pan should be at least warmish before you even add oil. With stainless, the pan does need to be at least a certain temperature before adding oil, iirc, around 200F. In either case, the main way you're going to have sticking with eggs is if the pan is too hot. Keep an eye on the heat--start out low if you don't know what you're doing--don't try to turn a part of the egg that hasn't solidified yet, it might help to use your spatula upside-down to check a corner, be persistent and you'll get it.

>>18881169
Most of the "ceramic" you see in the Walmart cookware department is really just a special type of polymer coating "infused with glass powder" and coated over an ordinary aluminum pan. Not bad for cooking at all, but stretching the definition of ceramic. IMO, true ceramic "stoneware/earthenware" is usually not really suitable for stovetop use, although you will sometimes see ceramic (not enameled cast iron) dutch ovens that say they're fine on a stove, and there are pyrex skillets out there, which are literally glass. As far as enameled cast iron, that's supposed to be pretty durable and easy to use, but the ceramic finish will eventually develop hairline cracks and chips.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18876648
Oh yeah, you fucking knew. When you are relying on school free lunch/breakfast to get you by, you sure as fuck knew you were poor. Hotdogs, beans, cheap ground meat. Anything on sale. Margarine. No spices, just salt, pepper, and garlic powder. Not even onion powder. Things got better, but yeah, I got trained hard in the art of depression style saving and cooking. Because I had to do it myself or starve.

Later on it got replaced with eating out because we came into money.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Grew up almost hillbilly poor but never realized it. My mom had a nice but small house. We ate a lot of beans and pasta and eggs from our coop. Must of our meat was game meat or trout caught nearby. We also usually had pork because she would buy half of a hog every year. We also grew a lot of zucchini, tomatoes and potatoes and had fruit trees. She canned a lot but i thought that was just how everyone ate so I didn't really know any better. I look back on it all fondly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Two embarrassing stories, our school had some kind of park outing. They ordered those giant 9 foot subway sandwiches for the class. Everyone was supposed to chip in a couple of dollars but my brother and I had nothing so we had to eat our pb&j sandwiches while all the other kids feasted.
Second one I was spending the day at a friends house. They decide to go out to dinner to some pizza place. Told me it was a family thing and I could come along but couldn't eat with them I had to buy my own food.
Now that I think about it that family were kind of assholes. That wasn't the first time they fucked with me. They knew we were dirt poor and they were rich. Probably why they never let me hang out with their kid again after that.
Being a poor kid living in a relatively well off neighborhood was hell. Everyone I knew at school/church was always going on ski trips and shit and we never got to go along with anything.

>>18876648
i wasn't particularly poor myself but my parents both grew up either very poor or in a family massive enough to have to worry about food costs between so many kids. as a result they continued a habit as adults of buying the absolute lowest priced value foods to the cent they could find even though they never needed to by the time me or my brother were old enough to care. they were actually really resourceful when it came to cooking so the food was good but occasionally i got some unfortunate stuff such as

>meat frozen so long it tasted like nothing by the time we did eat it
>the occasional expired dollar store food, never understood this because there was a legitimate grocery store literally next door with comparable prices
>mom would always yell at me for taking a pack of 2 poptarts instead of just 1 to school at age 13, where my morning was basically leaving the house at 5am for a long ass bus trip and no school lunch until noon
>incredibly low amounts of salt or spices ever used, didn't grasp this until it clicked why homemade plain chicken tasted nothing like restaurant chicken
>yelling over who opened a cereal
>yelling over who finished a pack of anything, but also yelling over who left a small amount of a pack of anything
>insistence that the same coffee grounds be reused, i thought coffee was just shit water until adulthood because this was obviously not good
>the occasional bizarre leftovers creation that was hit or miss, later learned that this was usually a result of my dad being bored. he still does this to this day and it's usually something pretty cool nowadays but he holds himself to such a high standard and expectations for what amounts to "mix of whatever is in the fridge"

however there was some stuff i really did like that i still eat now that im on my own, like cheap frozen fish and pierogis.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not poor but I'm a social worker.
I've seen three "types" of home, in the first three family has some money but is dysfunctional, all the food is junk food, the freezer is full of pizza, the fridge is full of soft drink. This isn't nearly as expensive as you might imagine because of how calorie dense these foods acrually are. Kids skip meals, throw tantrums when food runs out, binge eat, get fat.

In the second type of home there's no money but at least one tired and stressed family member cooks. Often it's monotonous and totally unseasoned, boiled frozen vegetables, pasta, boiled eggs. Meat offcuts or frozen hotdogs in a pan, boiled potatoes. There's a variant for every ethnicity, but this is actually far better nutrition wise.

Third household is begging and stealing, everyone hoards and hides food, the only things in the fridge are moldy or fouled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18881748
Buy in bulk, even cheaper brands are fine even if they don't taste as much. They also last very long so you're not wasting any of it.
The money I save by buying slightly less quality meat for a month can be used to buy said oils and spices that will last several months so when you got that down upgrade meat as budget allows. We're not talking about a full cabinet of 20 spices either, just the most basic ones. I'm assuming salt and pepper are not included so rosemary, thyme, oregano, chili and one or two more after preference. Obviously you can't expect getting fresh stuff constantly unless planting it yourself.

I just know I'd prefer more basic meals with a larger choice of spices and oils to make variations than simply upgrading the meat quality slightly and not having said stuff. Worst case you can get piece by piece as budget allows since it, again, lasts very long (oils and spices).

yeah, birthdays are pretty great.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18880522
You can't make any significant quantity of broth in the instant pot. A good broth/stock takes lots and lots of bones and time. You can either dedicate a Saturday or Sunday afternoon to making a batchbof broth to use during the week, or you can buy broth. Those're the options.

>>18880537
Stock/broth's expensive to make on its own thesev days. Sons o' bitches're gettin' $5/lb for beef soup bones. Fuckin' bones. I still buy and make my own because I have control over the final product, but god damn it's gettin' ridiculous. A week's worth of beef stock is nearly $50 in bones, herbs and aromatics. For the most basic kitchen essential.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18880593
>You can't make any significant quantity of broth in the instant pot. A good broth/stock takes lots and lots of bones and time.
Pressure cooking literally bypasses the requirement for time by increasing the boiling temperature of water. At atmospheric conditions, water can only ever get so hot, if it's boiling, it's 100C. Under pressure, it can get up to 150C. There is a non-linear relationship between temperature and cooking, you can make something that would take 5 hours of boiling in 30 minutes of pressure cooking. After 90 minutes of pressure cooking, chicken bones will come out soft and fragile, as though they just spent 12 hours simmering.

t. was skeptical of the reddit pot until I tried it at a friend's house a few times now (including a couple of times for chicken soup). Now I'm a believer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18880522
Those recipes are for one load of cooking. They ask for pre-made broth because you can't make broth while cooking the vegetables at the same time.
If you want to make your own broth, you first have to run the instant pot with chicken parts only to make the broth. Then you take it out and go on to make the recipe, re-adding the broth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18882778
You don't have to do any ratios with a rice cooker (and the anon above who said "1.5:1" completely ignored the fact that ratios differ depending on the type of rice, among other things). You simply measure out your rice with a standardized rice cup, rinse it, then fill the water up to the line in the bowl for the kind of rice you're making. After that you flip the switch and do literally nothing until it's done. I like to give it a quick stir/fluff when it's done, but after that your rice will be kept warm for (dozens of) hours. Oh yeah, it also makes much better rice than you're making on your stove. I'm not saying you can't make good rice without a rice cooker, or that you need to spend a decade at Jiro's, but most people simply can't make rice as good as a decent rice cooker can with 5 minutes of work involved. If you eat rice more than once a week it's a complete no-brainer. The quality of the end product and the ease of use just makes life easier and more enjoyable in every way. A few years back I was visiting my mom and she said something to the effect of, "you only talk about things you hate; is there anything you actually like?" And I told her I love my rice cooker. It's a little thing I spent $170 on 10 years ago and has boosted my happiness and enjoyment of life so much over the years it's almost immeasurable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18882336
you won't get into kann for another six months.

portland is an amazing food city but it really depends what you're looking for. my number one pick for breakfast spot would have to be Gravy. the biscuits and gravy are the best in town and when my normie family flies out here they can't get enough. it can be difficult to get in on weekends though.

dinner? my rotating favorites AT THE MOMENT are:

Afuri (my enduring favorite, top tier ramen and japanese, the SE location has best ambiance and the onky properly made sushi in town)

EEM (don't expect thai takeout prices- this shit is another level and has been top of my list for years)

Dolly Olive (newer, amazing fresh pasta and focaccia, the chicken confit is really good too but in my opinion the pastas and salads are peak)

Scotch Lodge (incredible american/asian fusion- sounds like bullshit but it is outstanding.)

if you want like food trucks and shit it's hard to fuck up. you can fuck up, but you have to try. i hope you enjoy your time here.

The thing about mushrooms and rinsing;
If you're cooking at home you can rinse them and cook with them right away and it's fine. They won't get soggy.

You're running a restaurant, however, you might get a big crate of mushrooms and Tuesday and clean them all so they're ready to use for the rest of the week. If you rinse those with water they might be soggy and sad by the end of the week, so you have to clean those with a dry brush instead.

>>18876997
What are you talking about? Most mushrooms in the grocery store (white button, portobello, baby bello, "stuffing mushrooms") are agaricus. They're highly carcinogenic if eaten raw. Scientists use agaritine to give rats tumors when they want to study cancer, that's how reliably carcinogenic it is.

Another info I have about grocery store mushrooms is that all the oyster species, such as blue/yellow/pink/pearl as well as the king trumpet, will trigger a serious allergic reaction in about 10% of the population if eaten raw. Basically if you're at all allergic to mold or mold spores then you're probably allergic to all the oyster species. It's not recommended to find out whether you fall into this camp.

>>18879288
Mushroom cultivator here. The procedure is that you make "grain spawn" (mycelium-colonized grains) as a way to quickly propagate mycelium. Then you use the grain spawn to inoculate larger bags of less nutritious bulk substrate for fruiting. Nobody fruits from grain, especially not commercially, because it would be a preposterous waste of money. White button mushrooms and portabellas are fruited in a sterilized compost/manure mixture. Yes it's cow shit and yes it's also literally clean enough to eat. You should wash mushrooms when they've been in the grocery store because people coughed on them, not because of the shit.

>. If I was like a wild animal man living out innawoods or whatever I probably wouldn't have the luxury of regimented meals... I think about that a lot.
If we could generalize hunter gatherers (95% of human existence, by far the most significant in our evolutionary history), they would eat something close to OMAD. They'd spend all day gathering and hunting and then eat a big meal before passing out for the evening. Then they wake up and start over again.
They had no way to preserve food long-term so a kill would last a couple of days at most.
Sometimes they wouldn't make a kill for a few days so they'd have to eat yesterday's leftovers (if any) and whatever could be foraged. I can't imagine they could afford any regularity in their meals at all, nor that they would waste time eating upon waking or during sunny hours when that time was crucial to forage and hunt in order to survive.

source: My ass, but there is no evidence to the contrary. Based on our understanding of hunter-gatherer life, it's much more likely than eating breakfast, lunch and dinner.

https://www.cbsnews.com/news/father-of-peeps-bob-born-dies-at-98/
>Bob Born was born in New York City on Sept. 29, 1924. His father, Sam Born, was a Russian immigrant who had founded Just Born Inc., a small candy company, in 1923. The family later moved to Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, where Just Born is still based. Bob Born graduated from Lehigh University with a degree in engineering physics. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy and served as a radar specialist and a lieutenant on a destroyer in the Pacific. Later, the Navy sent him to the University of Arizona and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for graduate work in math and physics.

>Born applied to medical school and was accepted, but while he was waiting for his classes to begin, he went to work at Just Born. He fell in love with the candy business and decided to stay. In 1953, Just Born acquired Rodda Candy Co., a jelly bean maker that had a side business producing shaped marshmallow candies by hand. At the time, it took about 27 hours to make the marshmallows. Bob Born saw the candies' potential, so he and an engineer at the company designed and built a machine to make them in less than six minutes. The company still uses a version of that machine.

>Seventy years later, Peeps remain Just Born's most recognizable candy brand, the company says. Just Born makes around 2 billion Peeps each year, or enough to circle the globe twice. It sells the most at Easter, but also has versions sold for Halloween, Valentine's Day and other holidays. Bob Born also came up with the recipe for another popular Just Born candy, Hot Tamales. Just Born also makes Mike and Ike fruit chews and Goldenberg's Peanut Chews.

>Bob Born became Just Born's president in 1959 and held the role for more than 30 years. He spent most of his retirement in Florida, where he led a literacy program and enjoyed hobbies including photography. He was active until a few months before he died, when he had a difficult recovery after a hard fall.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18873015
When I graduated from college, my mom was pretty sickly. Since I was available, it was deemed I'd be the one taking care of her. Nothing too heavy, give her pills, change oxygen tanks for her, cook meals, clean the house, etc. I got to live at home rent free, no job, lots of free time. I didn't have a lot of friends anymore, they were all moving on with their lives, moving away, getting jobs, getting married. But I had time for me. My sleep schedule was kinda shit because my mom would call me in the middle of the night for help with stuff. I watched a lot of late night tv. Specifically Good Eats, which was on from like 2am to 5am. I watched it every night. I learned a lot about cooking. Not just how to make A dish, but the science behind it and related dishes. I learned techniques I hadn't thought of before. I started experimenting more with my cooking. I'd buy new stuff I hadn't tried before, made exotic cuisines and fancy desserts. My mom loved it. It was a lot of fun for me and it turned cooking and baking into a passion I still have someone today. Mom is long gone now, and I don't really have the time and money to make a lot of the stuff I used to. But the spark is still there, buried under old embers, hoping to return one day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18882059
salt with coarse seasalt 1 day in advance and put in the fridge
cook it in the oven at 250f wrapped with foil until the internal temperature is 125 (should look a bit underdone). for steaks like that it will take 30-45 min.
rest for a bit then finish in an extremely hot pan or grill to get it crispy and brown.

The most important thing is making sure you don't overcook it in the pan/grill. It should be medium rare when it comes out of the oven and thus done. The pan step is just to get a brown crust on it, which can 't be done as effectively in the oven. But the oven step is crucial because the long slow cooking will make it very tender.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
5 mins each side on medium-high cast iron, 5 mins in preheated 250c+ oven, 5 minutes rest
use a meat thermometer if you're not sure

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18882059
Put as much Kosher salt as will stick to each side
Don't try to force it or it will be too salty
Put them on a wire rack on a sheet pan in your oven
Bring up the temp to 130-150F
Turn off the oven
Come back in 1.5 hours
Flip them
Bring the oven back up to 130-150F again, turn it off
Come back after 2.5 hours (total 4 hours)
Put a cast iron or oven safe steel pan in the oven
Pat the steaks dry
Get the pan up to 500F
Carefully put the pan on your stove
Stove on high
Fill the pan with a lot of oil, it needs to be 1/8 inch deep from side to side
This prevents the pan from smoking but if you have a hood, turn it on anyway
Fry the steak to your desired level of doneness
Using tongs, flip the steak on its side and cook the deckle, the crescent moon shaped meat on the top a little extra, the deckle should be cooked to medium-ish but the eye or loin round section is best on the rarer side
Don't use butter, if you want it to taste like butter, put butter on it after you cook it
Butter will not sear a steak
Butter steams the steak
Put the butter on when the steak is on a plate
Use a preheated plate

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Even if you decide to do them on the grill because you don't have enough stovetop, do the salt and 4 hours of drying in the low-temp oven
This is called a reverse sear
This dries out the surface and gives time for the salt to get deep into the meat
Those are pretty, don't bother with anything other than salt, put the rest of your effort into something like a compound butter, some really good mustard, and maybe a remoulade

tough also. usually dried and made into jerkey, or stewed. tail is good for soup. had a prime steak of it out the backstrap when my dad shot one and it was pretty good.

delicious, especially in early winter when they have a little fat on them

fatty, more flavourful chicken
